awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Copper Catalyzed Oxidative Decarboxylative Coupling Reactions for the Direct Functionalization of Arenes
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Catalysis program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Jessica Hoover of West Virginia University is developing new catalytic reactions for the formation of carbon-carbon (C-C) bonds from carboxylic acids through oxidative decarboxylative coupling reactions. This new method uses a copper catalyst to transform simple carboxylic acids and arenes into heterobiaryls and haloalkyl arenes that are relevant to pharmaceutical and biological molecules. This technology offers improvements over classical coupling methods, including the replacement of expensive, toxic, and wasteful organometallic reagents with inexpensive and readily available carboxylic acid starting materials while generating minimal waste. 

The formation of C-C bonds are key steps in the construction of complex structures and the successful development of this methodology will enable the design of new, more efficient catalysts for the formation of C-C bonds by the pharmaceutical and fine chemical industries. Professor Hoover is actively engaged in the integration of research and education at the undergraduate level partly by involving undergraduates in the research laboratory and partly by incorporating research experiments and concepts into the undergraduate curriculum. This award also supports the development of a new summer program designed to bring together chemists, engineers, and artists to work toward the common goal of building a public science-art installation. The program is designed to initiate a meaningful dialog of science within the local Morgantown community, to help student participants communicate effectively between science, the humanities, and art, and with the broader public sphere.

por.por_cntn:
Carbon-carbon (C-C) bonds form the basis of all organic molecules making reactions that form these bonds key steps in the synthesis of biologically active and pharmaceutically relevant molecules. Traditional routes to make C-C bonds have poor atom- and step-economy and there is a need for new routes to access these targets from simple and readily available starting materials under conditions that are mild and sustainable. The central goal of this program was to develop decarboxylative coupling reactions that use stable and abundant benzoic acids as coupling partners for new C-C bond forming reactions. Our work in this area uncovered several new decarboxylative arylation reactions to form C-C bond and decarboxylative thiolation reactions to form new C-S bonds. We reported the first examples of Cu-catalyzed reactions of these types and also disclosed a decarboxylative arylation that is capable of the coupling of a wide scope of heteroaromatic carboxylate coupling partners. While these reactions provide a new route to access functionalized arenes of biological importance, the most important findings from this work are related to the limitations of these reactions. For example, these reactions are often limited to the coupling of specific benzoic acids, such as 2-nitrobenzoic acid. We performed detailed kinetic studies to address the origin of this limitation and identified the field effect (F), a though-space electronic effect, to be responsible for the limited substrate scope. With this understanding we were able to expand the scope of coupling partners to others with larger F values.

Another limitation of these reactions is the oxidants required. Many of the decarboxylative coupling reactions identified rely on the use of silver salts as stoichiometric oxidants because they facilitate the decarboxylation step. The use of air (or O2) as the oxidant would be a more attractive alternative, but few systems are capable of selective catalysis under aerobic conditions. We identified a copper-catalyzed decarboxylative thiolation reaction that proceeds efficiently while using O2 as the sole oxidant. To probe the function of O2 in this reaction, we conducted a thorough mechanistic study, including kinetic measurements and reactivity studies of well-defined complexes. Our findings demonstrated a role for O2 in generating the disulfide (RSSR) from the thiol (RSH) as well as enabling catalytic turnover via oxidative dissociation of an otherwise tightly bound thiolate ligand. Our studies also indicated the importance of copper(I) intermediates in this reaction. In particular decarboxylation occurs via a copper(I) carboxylate species, despite the oxidizing conditions. These studies will facilitate the replacement of silver salt oxidants with O2 in other oxidative decarboxylative coupling reactions. The development and mechanistic understanding of these new reactions are impactful because they lay the groundwork for the efficient synthesis of biologically relevant structures from simple and stable benzoic acid starting materials under mild and sustainable conditions.

This work has resulted in the publication of 10 peer-reviewed articles and has served as a platform for the training and mentorship of 13 undergraduate students, many of whom have gone on to graduate or professional programs following graduation. This award also supported the new Community Engagement in Science Through Art (CESTA) summer program. For each of the four summers of this program, a small team of students from diverse disciplines and at different stages of their education (undergraduate and graduate students) worked collaboratively to design and build a public chemistry-art installation. Throughout the program student participants developed their cross-disciplinary collaboration and communication skills and each year the students exceeded expectations creating beautiful and interactive pieces that sparked scientific curiosity and chemistry conversations within the local community.
